title: How to Make Glitter Candlesticks

steps.headline: Lay newspaper over the work space.
steps.description: Place a square of brown paper/flat paper bag or a paper bowl directly under the spot you're going to be working on, to catch loose glitter for reuse. A lot of glitter will fall off when making this project and it's worth rescuing.

steps.headline: Paint glue or hard coat Mod Podge on the candlesticks in sections.
steps.description: Paint a small section of glue at the base of the first candlestick. This prevents the glue from drying before you can get glitter onto it. Sections of about 2.5-5cm/1-2 inches are about enough to cover in one go.

steps.headline: Decide whether or not you're happy with the amount of glitter cover.
steps.description: If you are, move on to the next step. If not, apply a new coat of glue or Mod Podge and add more glitter. Allow to dry before moving on.

steps.headline: Sprinkle glitter over the painted area.
steps.description: Cover completely. As with the previous step, check that you're happy with the amount of glitter applied. Let dry before moving to the next step.

steps.headline: Paint glue on the next section, working your way up the candlestick.
steps.description: Sprinkle the glitter over the painted section to cover completely. Add another layer of glue/Mod Podge and glitter each time, if needed.

steps.headline: Continue in this manner until you reach the top of the candlestick.
steps.description: However, do not place any glitter or Mod Podge on the dish part/upper side where the candle sits––no need to tempt flammability. Instead, finish up underneath the holder lip. Let dry at least 24 hours before using.

steps.headline: Paint a thin layer of shellac over the glittery candlesticks.
steps.description: This will seal the glitter in place.

text: Adding glitter Lay newspaper over the work space. Place a square of brown paper/flat paper bag or a paper bowl directly under the spot you're going to be working on, to catch loose glitter for reuse. A lot of glitter will fall off when making this project and it's worth rescuing. Paint glue or hard coat Mod Podge on the candlesticks in sections. Paint a small section of glue at the base of the first candlestick. This prevents the glue from drying before you can get glitter onto it. Sections of about 2.5-5cm/1-2 inches are about enough to cover in one go. Decide whether or not you're happy with the amount of glitter cover. If you are, move on to the next step. If not, apply a new coat of glue or Mod Podge and add more glitter. Allow to dry before moving on. Sprinkle glitter over the painted area. Cover completely. As with the previous step, check that you're happy with the amount of glitter applied. Let dry before moving to the next step. Paint glue on the next section, working your way up the candlestick. Sprinkle the glitter over the painted section to cover completely. Add another layer of glue/Mod Podge and glitter each time, if needed. Continue in this manner until you reach the top of the candlestick. However, do not place any glitter or Mod Podge on the dish part/upper side where the candle sits––no need to tempt flammability. Instead, finish up underneath the holder lip. Let dry at least 24 hours before using. Finishing off Paint a thin layer of shellac over the glittery candlesticks. This will seal the glitter in place. Finished.
